# East India Company

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

This article is about the 16th–19th-century English and British trading
company. For the current East India Company (founded 2010), see [Sanjiv
Mehta](/wiki/Sanjiv_Mehta "Sanjiv Mehta"). For other uses, see [East India
Company (disambiguation)](/wiki/East_India_Company_\(disambiguation\) "East
India Company \(disambiguation\)").

"HEIC" redirects here. For other uses, see [HEIC
(disambiguation)](/wiki/HEIC_\(disambiguation\) "HEIC \(disambiguation\)").

The **East India Company** (**EIC**), also known as the **Honourable East
India Company** (**HEIC**) or the **British East India Company** and
informally as **John Company** ,[1] was an English and later British [joint-
stock company](/wiki/Joint-stock_company "Joint-stock company"),[2] which was
formed to pursue trade with the "[East Indies](/wiki/East_Indies "East
Indies")" (in present-day terms, [Maritime Southeast
Asia](/wiki/Maritime_Southeast_Asia "Maritime Southeast Asia")), but ended up
trading mainly with [Qing China](/wiki/Qing_China "Qing China") and seizing
control of the [Indian subcontinent](/wiki/Indian_subcontinent "Indian
subcontinent").

Originally chartered as the "Governor and Company of Merchants of London
trading into the East Indies", the company rose to account for half of the
world's trade, particularly in basic commodities including cotton, silk,
[indigo dye](/wiki/Indigo_dye "Indigo dye"), salt, [saltpetre](/wiki/Saltpetre
"Saltpetre"), tea and [opium](/wiki/Opium "Opium"). The company also ruled the
beginnings of the [British Empire](/wiki/British_Empire "British Empire") in
India.[3]

The company received a [Royal Charter](/wiki/Royal_Charter "Royal Charter")
from [Queen Elizabeth I](/wiki/Elizabeth_I_of_England "Elizabeth I of
England") on 31 December 1600, making it the oldest among several similarly
formed European [East India
Companies](/wiki/East_India_Company_\(disambiguation\) "East India Company
\(disambiguation\)"). Wealthy merchants and [aristocrats](/wiki/Aristocracy
"Aristocracy") owned the company's shares.[4] Initially the government owned
no shares and had only indirect control.

During its first century of operation, the focus of the company was trade, not
the building of an empire in India. Company interests turned from trade to
territory during the 18th century as the [Mughal Empire](/wiki/Mughal_Empire
"Mughal Empire") declined in power and the East India Company struggled with
its French counterpart, the [French East India
Company](/wiki/French_East_India_Company "French East India Company")
(_Compagnie française des Indes orientales_) during the [Carnatic
Wars](/wiki/Carnatic_Wars "Carnatic Wars") of the 1740s and 1750s. The [Battle
of Plassey](/wiki/Battle_of_Plassey "Battle of Plassey") and [Battle of
Buxar](/wiki/Battle_of_Buxar "Battle of Buxar"), in which the British, led by
[Robert Clive](/wiki/Robert_Clive "Robert Clive"), defeated the Indian powers,
left the company in control of [Bengal](/wiki/Bengal_Presidency "Bengal
Presidency") and a major military and political power in India. In the
following decades it gradually increased the extent of the territories under
its control, ruling the whole Indian subcontinent either directly or
indirectly via local puppet rulers under the threat of force by its
[Presidency armies](/wiki/Presidency_armies "Presidency armies"), much of
which were composed of native Indian [sepoys](/wiki/Sepoys "Sepoys").

By 1803, at the height of its rule in India, the British East India company
had a private army of about 260,000—twice the size of the [British
Army](/wiki/British_Army "British Army").[5] The company eventually came to
rule large areas of India with [its private armies](/wiki/Presidency_armies
"Presidency armies"), exercising military power and assuming administrative
functions.[6] [Company rule in India](/wiki/Company_rule_in_India "Company
rule in India") effectively began in 1757 and lasted until 1858, when,
following the [Indian Rebellion of 1857](/wiki/Indian_Rebellion_of_1857
"Indian Rebellion of 1857"), the [Government of India Act
1858](/wiki/Government_of_India_Act_1858 "Government of India Act 1858") led
to the [British Crown](/wiki/British_Crown "British Crown")'s assuming direct
control of the Indian subcontinent in the form of the new [British
Raj](/wiki/British_Raj "British Raj").

Despite frequent government intervention, the company had recurring problems
with its finances. It was dissolved in 1874 as a result of the [East India
Stock Dividend Redemption
Act](/wiki/East_India_Stock_Dividend_Redemption_Act_1873 "East India Stock
Dividend Redemption Act 1873") passed one year earlier, as the Government of
India Act had by then rendered it vestigial, powerless, and obsolete. The
official [government machinery](/wiki/Machinery_of_government "Machinery of
government") of [British India](/wiki/British_India "British India") had
assumed its governmental functions and absorbed its armies.

## Founding[[edit](/w/index.php?title=East_India_Company&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Founding")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/Jameslancaster.jpg/170px-
Jameslancaster.jpg)](/wiki/File:Jameslancaster.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Jameslancaster.jpg "Enlarge")

[James Lancaster](/wiki/James_Lancaster "James Lancaster") commanded the first
East India Company voyage in 1601

Soon after the defeat of the [Spanish Armada](/wiki/Spanish_Armada "Spanish
Armada") in 1588, London merchants presented a petition to [Queen Elizabeth
I](/wiki/Elizabeth_I_of_England "Elizabeth I of England") for permission to
sail to the Indian Ocean.[7] Permission was granted, and on 10 April 1591
three ships sailed from [Torbay](/wiki/Torbay "Torbay") around the [Cape of
Good Hope](/wiki/Cape_of_Good_Hope "Cape of Good Hope") to the [Arabian
Sea](/wiki/Arabian_Sea "Arabian Sea") on one of the earliest English overseas
Indian expeditions. One of them, _[Edward
Bonaventure](/wiki/English_ship_Bonaventure_\(1567\) "English ship Bonaventure
\(1567\)")_ , then sailed around [Cape Comorin](/wiki/Cape_Comorin "Cape
Comorin") to the [Malay Peninsula](/wiki/Malay_Peninsula "Malay Peninsula")
and returned to England in 1594.[7]

In 1596, three more ships sailed east but were all lost at sea.[7] Three years
later, on 22 September 1599,[8] another group of merchants met and stated
their intention "to venture in the pretended voyage to the East Indies (the
which it may please the Lord to prosper), and the sums that they will
adventure", committing £30,133.[9] Two days later, on 24 September, "the
Adventurers" reconvened and resolved to apply to the Queen for support of the
project.[9] Although their first attempt had not been completely successful,
they nonetheless sought the Queen's unofficial approval to continue, bought
ships for their venture and increased their capital to £68,373.

The Adventurers convened again a year later.[7] This time they succeeded, and
on 31 December 1600, the Queen granted a [Royal Charter](/wiki/Royal_Charter
"Royal Charter") to "[George, Earl of
Cumberland](/wiki/George_Clifford,_3rd_Earl_of_Cumberland "George Clifford,
3rd Earl of Cumberland"), and 215 [Knights](/wiki/Knight "Knight"),
[Aldermen](/wiki/Aldermen "Aldermen"), and [Burgesses](/wiki/Burgess_\(title\)
"Burgess \(title\)")" under the name, **Governor and Company of Merchants of
London trading with the East Indies**.[10] For a period of fifteen years the
charter awarded the newly formed company a monopoly on trade with all
countries east of the [Cape of Good Hope](/wiki/Cape_of_Good_Hope "Cape of
Good Hope") and west of the [Straits of Magellan](/wiki/Straits_of_Magellan
"Straits of Magellan").[10] Any traders in breach of the charter without a
licence from the company were liable to forfeiture of their ships and cargo
(half of which went to the Crown and the other half to the company), as well
as imprisonment at the "royal pleasure".[11]

The governance of the company was in the hands of one governor and 24
[directors](/wiki/British_East_India_Company_directors "British East India
Company directors") or "committees", who made up the Court of Directors. They,
in turn, reported to the Court of Proprietors, which appointed them. Ten
committees reported to the Court of Directors. According to tradition,
business was initially transacted at the Nags Head Inn, opposite [St
Botolph's](/wiki/St_Botolph-without-Bishopsgate "St Botolph-without-
Bishopsgate") church in [Bishopsgate](/wiki/Bishopsgate "Bishopsgate"), before
moving to India House in [Leadenhall Street](/wiki/Leadenhall_Street
"Leadenhall Street").[12]

## Early voyages to the East
Indies[[edit](/w/index.php?title=East_India_Company&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Early voyages to the East Indies")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/East_India_House_by_Thomas_Malton_the_Younger.jpg/220px-
East_India_House_by_Thomas_Malton_the_Younger.jpg)](/wiki/File:East_India_House_by_Thomas_Malton_the_Younger.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:East_India_House_by_Thomas_Malton_the_Younger.jpg "Enlarge")

[East India House](/wiki/East_India_House "East India House"), London, painted
by [Thomas Malton](/wiki/Thomas_Malton "Thomas Malton") in c.1800

Sir [James Lancaster](/wiki/James_Lancaster "James Lancaster") commanded the
first East India Company voyage in 1601[13] and returned in 1603.[14] In March
1604 [Sir Henry Middleton](/wiki/Sir_Henry_Middleton "Sir Henry Middleton")
commanded the [second voyage](/wiki/Second_voyage_to_Asia "Second voyage to
Asia"). General [William Keeling](/wiki/William_Keeling "William Keeling"), a
captain during the second voyage, led the third voyage aboard the _[Red
Dragon](/wiki/Red_Dragon_\(1595\) "Red Dragon \(1595\)")_ from 1607 to 1610
along with the _Hector_ under Captain [William
Hawkins](/wiki/Sir_William_Hawkins "Sir William Hawkins") and the _Consent_
under Captain [David Middleton](/wiki/David_Middleton_\(mariner\) "David
Middleton \(mariner\)").[15]

Early in 1608 [Alexander Sharpeigh](/wiki/Alexander_Sharpeigh "Alexander
Sharpeigh") was appointed captain of the company's _Ascension_ , and general
or commander of the fourth voyage. Thereafter two ships, _Ascension_ and
_Union_ (captained by Richard Rowles) sailed from Woolwich on 14 March
1607–08.[15]

Initially, the company struggled in the [spice trade](/wiki/Spice_trade "Spice
trade") because of the competition from the already well-established [Dutch
East India Company](/wiki/Dutch_East_India_Company "Dutch East India
Company"). The company opened a [factory](/wiki/Factory_\(trading_post\)
"Factory \(trading post\)") in [Bantam](/wiki/Bantam_\(city\) "Bantam
\(city\)") on the first voyage, and imports of [pepper](/wiki/Black_pepper
"Black pepper") from [Java](/wiki/Java "Java") were an important part of the
company's trade for twenty years. The factory in Bantam was closed in 1683.
During this time ships belonging to the company arriving in India docked at
[Surat](/wiki/Surat "Surat"), which was established as a trade transit point
in 1608.

In the next two years, the company established its first factory in south
India in the town of [Machilipatnam](/wiki/Machilipatnam "Machilipatnam") on
the [Coromandel Coast](/wiki/Coromandel_Coast "Coromandel Coast") of the [Bay
of Bengal](/wiki/Bay_of_Bengal "Bay of Bengal"). The high profits reported by
the company after landing in India initially prompted [King James
I](/wiki/James_I_of_England "James I of England") to grant subsidiary licences
to other trading companies in England. But in 1609 he renewed the charter
given to the company for an indefinite period, including a clause that
specified that the charter would cease to be in force if the trade turned
unprofitable for three consecutive years.

## Foothold in
India[[edit](/w/index.php?title=East_India_Company&action=edit&section=3 "Edit
section: Foothold in India")]

See also: [Establishment of English trade in Bengal
(1600–1700)](/wiki/History_of_Kolkata#Establishment_of_English_trade_in_Bengal_.281600.E2.80.931700.29
"History of Kolkata")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/Reddragonship.jpg/220px-
Reddragonship.jpg)](/wiki/File:Reddragonship.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Reddragonship.jpg "Enlarge")

[_Red Dragon_](/wiki/Red_Dragon_\(1595\) "Red Dragon \(1595\)") fought the
Portuguese at the [Battle of Swally](/wiki/Battle_of_Swally "Battle of
Swally") in 1612, and made several voyages to the [East
Indies](/wiki/East_Indies "East Indies").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Jahangir_investing_a_courtier_with_a_robe_of_honour_watched_by_Sir_Thomas_Roe%2C_English_ambassador_to_the_court_of_Jahangir_at_Agra_from_1615-18%2C_and_others.jpg/220px-
Jahangir_investing_a_courtier_with_a_robe_of_honour_watched_by_Sir_Thomas_Roe%2C_English_ambassador_to_the_court_of_Jahangir_at_Agra_from_1615-18%2C_and_others.jpg)](/wiki/File:Jahangir_investing_a_courtier_with_a_robe_of_honour_watched_by_Sir_Thomas_Roe,_English_ambassador_to_the_court_of_Jahangir_at_Agra_from_1615-18,_and_others.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Jahangir_investing_a_courtier_with_a_robe_of_honour_watched_by_Sir_Thomas_Roe,_English_ambassador_to_the_court_of_Jahangir_at_Agra_from_1615-18,_and_others.jpg
"Enlarge")

Jahangir investing a courtier with a robe of honour, watched by Sir Thomas
Roe, English ambassador to the court of Jahangir at Agra from 1615 to 1618,
and others

English traders frequently engaged in hostilities with their Dutch and
Portuguese counterparts in the Indian Ocean. The company achieved a major
victory over the Portuguese in the [Battle of Swally](/wiki/Battle_of_Swally
"Battle of Swally") in 1612, at [Suvali](/wiki/Suvali "Suvali") in
[Surat](/wiki/Surat "Surat"). The company decided to explore the feasibility
of gaining a territorial foothold in mainland India, with official sanction
from both Britain and the [Mughal Empire](/wiki/Mughal_Empire "Mughal
Empire"), and requested that the Crown launch a diplomatic mission.[16]

In 1612, James I instructed Sir [Thomas Roe](/wiki/Thomas_Roe "Thomas Roe") to
visit the Mughal Emperor Nuruddin Salim [Jahangir](/wiki/Jahangir "Jahangir")
(r. 1605–1627) to arrange for a commercial treaty that would give the company
exclusive rights to reside and establish factories in Surat and other areas.
In return, the company offered to provide the Emperor with goods and rarities
from the European market. This mission was highly successful, and Jahangir
sent a letter to James through Sir Thomas Roe:[16]

> Upon which assurance of your royal love I have given my general command to
> all the kingdoms and ports of my dominions to receive all the merchants of
> the English nation as the subjects of my friend; that in what place soever
> they choose to live, they may have free liberty without any restraint; and
> at what port soever they shall arrive, that neither Portugal nor any other
> shall dare to molest their quiet; and in what city soever they shall have
> residence, I have commanded all my governors and captains to give them
> freedom answerable to their own desires; to sell, buy, and to transport into
> their country at their pleasure. For confirmation of our love and
> friendship, I desire your Majesty to command your merchants to bring in
> their ships of all sorts of rarities and rich goods fit for my palace; and
> that you be pleased to send me your royal letters by every opportunity, that
> I may rejoice in your health and prosperous affairs; that our friendship may
> be interchanged and eternal.
>
> — Nuruddin Salim Jahangir, Letter to James I.

Eventually, the East India Company seized control of Bengal and slowly the
whole Indian subcontinent with its private armies, composed primarily of
Indian [sepoys](/wiki/Sepoy "Sepoy"). As historian [William
Dalrymple](/wiki/William_Dalrymple_\(historian\) "William Dalrymple
\(historian\)") observes,

> We still talk about the British conquering India, but that phrase disguises
> a more sinister reality. It was not the British government that seized India
> at the end of the 18th century, but a dangerously unregulated private
> company headquartered in one small office, five windows wide, in London, and
> managed in India by an unstable [sociopath](/wiki/Sociopathy "Sociopathy") –
> [[Robert] Clive](/wiki/Robert_Clive "Robert Clive").[5]

##
Expansion[[edit](/w/index.php?title=East_India_Company&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Expansion")]

The company, which benefited from the imperial patronage, soon expanded its
commercial trading operations. It eclipsed the Portuguese [Estado da
Índia](/wiki/Estado_da_%C3%8Dndia "Estado da Índia"), which had established
bases in [Goa](/wiki/Goa "Goa"), [Chittagong](/wiki/Chittagong "Chittagong"),
and [Bombay](/wiki/Bombay "Bombay"), which Portugal later ceded to England as
part of the [dowry](/wiki/Dowry "Dowry") of [Catherine of
Braganza](/wiki/Catherine_of_Braganza "Catherine of Braganza"). The East India
Company also launched a joint attack with the Dutch [United East India
Company](/wiki/United_East_India_Company "United East India Company") (VOC) on
Portuguese and Spanish ships off the coast of China, which helped secure EIC
ports in China.[17] The company established [trading posts](/wiki/Trading_post
"Trading post") in [Surat](/wiki/Surat "Surat") (1619), [Madras](/wiki/Chennai
"Chennai") (1639), Bombay (1668), and [Calcutta](/wiki/Calcutta "Calcutta")
(1690). By 1647, the company had 23 factories, each under the command of a
[factor](/wiki/Factor_\(agent\) "Factor \(agent\)") or master merchant and
governor, and 90 employees[_[clarification
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Please_clarify "Wikipedia:Please clarify")_] in India.
The major factories became the walled forts of [Fort
William](/wiki/Fort_William,_India "Fort William, India") in Bengal, [Fort St
George](/wiki/Fort_St_George "Fort St George") in Madras, and [Bombay
Castle](/wiki/Bombay_Castle "Bombay Castle").

In 1634, the Mughal emperor extended his hospitality to the English traders to
the region of [Bengal](/wiki/Bengal "Bengal"), and in 1717 completely waived
customs duties for their trade. The company's mainstay businesses were by then
cotton, silk, [indigo dye](/wiki/Indigo_dye "Indigo dye"),
[saltpetre](/wiki/Potassium_nitrate "Potassium nitrate"), and tea. The Dutch
were aggressive competitors and had meanwhile expanded their monopoly of the
spice trade in the [Straits of Malacca](/wiki/Straits_of_Malacca "Straits of
Malacca") by ousting the Portuguese in 1640–41. With reduced Portuguese and
Spanish influence in the region, the EIC and VOC entered a period of intense
competition, resulting in the [Anglo-Dutch Wars](/wiki/Anglo-Dutch_Wars
"Anglo-Dutch Wars") of the 17th and 18th centuries.

In 1657, [Oliver Cromwell](/wiki/Oliver_Cromwell "Oliver Cromwell") renewed
the charter of 1609, and brought about minor changes in the holding of the
company. The restoration of monarchy in England further enhanced the EIC's
status.

In an act aimed at strengthening the power of the EIC, [King Charles
II](/wiki/Charles_II_of_England "Charles II of England") granted the EIC (in a
series of five acts around 1670) the rights to autonomous territorial
acquisitions, to mint money, to command fortresses and troops and form
alliances, to make war and peace, and to exercise both civil and criminal
jurisdiction over the acquired areas.[18]

[William Hedges](/wiki/William_Hedges_\(colonial_administrator\) "William
Hedges \(colonial administrator\)") was sent in 1682 to [Shaista
Khan](/wiki/Shaista_Khan "Shaista Khan"), the Mughal governor of Bengal, to
obtain a [firman](/wiki/Firman "Firman"), an imperial directive that would
grant England regular trading privileges throughout the Mughal Empire.
However, the company's governor in London, Sir [Josiah
Child](/wiki/Josiah_Child "Josiah Child"), interfered with Hedges's mission,
causing Mughal Emperor [Aurangzeb](/wiki/Aurangzeb "Aurangzeb") to break off
the negotiations.

In 1689 a Mughal fleet commanded by [Sidi Yaqub](/wiki/Sidi_Yaqub "Sidi
Yaqub") attacked Bombay. After a year of resistance the EIC surrendered in
1690, and the company sent envoys to Aurangzeb's camp to plead for a pardon.
The company's envoys had to prostrate themselves before the emperor, pay a
large indemnity, and promise better behaviour in the future. The emperor
withdrew his troops and the company subsequently re-established itself in
Bombay and set up a new base in Calcutta.[19]

The company eventually came to rule large areas of the Indian subcontinent
with its private armies, primarily composed of Indian [sepoys](/wiki/Sepoy
"Sepoy"), exercising military power and assuming administrative functions.

### Japan[[edit](/w/index.php?title=East_India_Company&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Japan")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/Bodleian_Library_MS._Jap._b.2_Shuinjo.jpg/220px-
Bodleian_Library_MS._Jap._b.2_Shuinjo.jpg)](/wiki/File:Bodleian_Library_MS._Jap._b.2_Shuinjo.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Bodleian_Library_MS._Jap._b.2_Shuinjo.jpg "Enlarge")

Document with the original [vermilion](/wiki/Vermilion "Vermilion") seal of
Tokugawa Ieyasu, granting trade privileges in Japan to the East India Company
in 1613

In 1613, during the rule of [Tokugawa Hidetada](/wiki/Tokugawa_Hidetada
"Tokugawa Hidetada") of the [Tokugawa shogunate](/wiki/Tokugawa_shogunate
"Tokugawa shogunate"), the British ship _[Clove](/wiki/Clove_\(ship\) "Clove
\(ship\)")_ , under the command of Captain [John Saris](/wiki/John_Saris "John
Saris"), was the first British ship to call on Japan. Saris was the chief
factor of the EIC's trading post in [Java](/wiki/Java "Java"), and with the
assistance of [William Adams](/wiki/William_Adams_\(sailor\) "William Adams
\(sailor\)"), a British sailor who had arrived in Japan in 1600, was able to
gain permission from the ruler to establish a commercial house in
[Hirado](/wiki/Hirado,_Nagasaki "Hirado, Nagasaki") on the Japanese island of
[Kyushu](/wiki/Kyushu "Kyushu"):

> We give free license to the subjects of the King of Great Britaine, Sir
> Thomas Smythe, Governor and Company of the East Indian Merchants and
> Adventurers forever safely come into any of our ports of our Empire of Japan
> with their shippes and merchandise, without any hindrance to them or their
> goods, and to abide, buy, sell and barter according to their own manner with
> all nations, to tarry here as long as they think good, and to depart at
> their pleasure.[20]

However, unable to obtain Japanese [raw silk](/wiki/Raw_silk "Raw silk") for
import to China and with their trading area reduced to Hirado and
[Nagasaki](/wiki/Nagasaki "Nagasaki") from 1616 onwards, in 1623 the company
closed their factory.[21]

### Mughal convoy piracy incident of
1695[[edit](/w/index.php?title=East_India_Company&action=edit&section=6 "Edit
section: Mughal convoy piracy incident of 1695")]

In September 1695, Captain [Henry Every](/wiki/Henry_Every "Henry Every"), an
English pirate on board the _[Fancy](/wiki/Fancy_\(ship\) "Fancy \(ship\)")_ ,
reached the Straits of [Bab-el-Mandeb](/wiki/Bab-el-Mandeb "Bab-el-Mandeb"),
where he teamed up with five other pirate captains to make an attack on the
Indian fleet making the annual voyage to [Mocha](/wiki/Mocha,_Yemen "Mocha,
Yemen"). The Mughal convoy included the treasure-laden _[Ganj-i-
Sawai](/wiki/Ganj-i-Sawai "Ganj-i-Sawai")_ , reported to be the greatest in
the Mughal fleet and the largest ship operational in the Indian Ocean, and its
escort, the _Fateh Muhammed_. They were spotted passing the straits en route
to [Surat](/wiki/Surat "Surat"). The pirates gave chase and caught up with
_Fateh Muhammed_ some days later, and meeting little resistance, took some
£50,000 to £60,000 worth of treasure.[22]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Mocha_Dapper_1680.jpg/220px-
Mocha_Dapper_1680.jpg)](/wiki/File:Mocha_Dapper_1680.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Mocha_Dapper_1680.jpg "Enlarge")

English, Dutch and Danish factories at [Mocha](/wiki/Mocha,_Yemen "Mocha,
Yemen")

Every continued in pursuit and managed to overhaul _Ganj-i-Sawai_ , which
resisted strongly before eventually [striking](/wiki/Striking_the_colours
"Striking the colours"). _Ganj-i-Sawai_ carried enormous wealth and, according
to contemporary East India Company sources, was carrying a relative of the
Grand Mughal, though there is no evidence to suggest that it was his daughter
and her retinue. The loot from the _Ganj-i-Sawai_ had a total value between
£325,000 and £600,000, including 500,000 gold and silver pieces, and has
become known as the richest ship ever taken by pirates.

In a letter sent to the Privy Council by Sir [John
Gayer](/wiki/John_Gayer_\(died_1711\) "John Gayer \(died 1711\)"), then
governor of Bombay and head of the East India Company, Gayer claims that "it
is certain the Pirates ... did do very barbarously by the People of the Ganj-
i-Sawai and Abdul Ghaffar's ship, to make them confess where their money was."
The pirates set free the survivors who were left aboard their emptied ships,
to continue their voyage back to India.

When the news arrived in England it caused an outcry. In response, a combined
bounty of £1,000 was offered for Every's capture by the Privy Council and East
India Company, leading to the first worldwide manhunt in recorded history. The
plunder of Aurangzeb's treasure ship had serious consequences for the English
East India Company. The furious Mughal Emperor Aurangzeb ordered Sidi Yaqub
and [Nawab Daud Khan](/wiki/Nawab_Daud_Khan "Nawab Daud Khan") to attack and
close four of the company's factories in India and imprison their officers,
who were almost lynched by a mob of angry [Mughals](/wiki/Mughal_\(tribe\)
"Mughal \(tribe\)"), blaming them for their countryman's depredations, and
threatened to put an end to all English trading in India. To appease Emperor
Aurangzeb and particularly his [Grand Vizier](/wiki/Grand_Vizier "Grand
Vizier") Asad Khan, Parliament exempted Every from all of the Acts of Grace
(pardons) and amnesties it would subsequently issue to other pirates.[23]

  * [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/Henry_Every.gif/101px-Henry_Every.gif)](/wiki/File:Henry_Every.gif)

An 18th-century depiction of [Henry Every](/wiki/Henry_Every "Henry Every"),
with the _Fancy_ shown engaging its prey in the background

  * [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/Every_engaging_the_Great_Mogul%27s_Ship.jpg/120px-Every_engaging_the_Great_Mogul%27s_Ship.jpg)](/wiki/File:Every_engaging_the_Great_Mogul%27s_Ship.jpg)

British pirates that fought during the Child's War engaging the [Ganj-i-
Sawai](/wiki/Ganj-i-Sawai "Ganj-i-Sawai")

  * [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Captain_Every_%28Works_of_Daniel_Defoe%29.png/120px-Captain_Every_%28Works_of_Daniel_Defoe%29.png)](/wiki/File:Captain_Every_\(Works_of_Daniel_Defoe\).png)

Depiction of [Captain Every](/wiki/Henry_Every "Henry Every")'s encounter with

Mughal trader Ganj-i-Sawai

## Forming a complete
monopoly[[edit](/w/index.php?title=East_India_Company&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Forming a complete monopoly")]

### Trade
monopoly[[edit](/w/index.php?title=East_India_Company&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Trade monopoly")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/Rear_view_of_the_East_India_Company%27s_Factory_at_Cossimbazar.jpg/220px-
Rear_view_of_the_East_India_Company%27s_Factory_at_Cossimbazar.jpg)](/wiki/File:Rear_view_of_the_East_India_Company%27s_Factory_at_Cossimbazar.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Rear_view_of_the_East_India_Company%27s_Factory_at_Cossimbazar.jpg
"Enlarge")

Rear view of the East India Company's Factory at Cossimbazar

The prosperity that the officers of the company enjoyed allowed them to return
to Britain and establish sprawling estates and businesses, and to obtain
political power. The company developed a [lobby](/wiki/Lobbying "Lobbying") in
the English parliament. Under pressure from ambitious tradesmen and former
associates of the company (pejoratively termed _Interlopers_ by the company),
who wanted to establish private trading firms in India, a deregulating act was
passed in 1694.[24]

This allowed any English firm to trade with India, unless specifically
prohibited by act of parliament, thereby annulling the charter that had been
in force for almost 100 years. By an act that was passed in 1698, a new
"parallel" East India Company (officially titled the _English Company Trading
to the East Indies_) was floated under a state-backed indemnity of £2 million.
The powerful stockholders of the old company quickly subscribed a sum of
£315,000 in the new concern, and dominated the new body. The two companies
wrestled with each other for some time, both in England and in India, for a
dominant share of the trade.[24]

It quickly became evident that, in practice, the original company faced
scarcely any measurable competition. The companies merged in 1708, by a
tripartite indenture involving both companies and the state. Under this
arrangement, the merged company lent to the Treasury a sum of £3,200,000, in
return for exclusive privileges for the next three years, after which the
situation was to be reviewed. The amalgamated company became the _United
Company of Merchants of England Trading to the East Indies_.[24]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Portrait_of_East_India_Company_official.jpg/200px-
Portrait_of_East_India_Company_official.jpg)](/wiki/File:Portrait_of_East_India_Company_official.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Portrait_of_East_India_Company_official.jpg "Enlarge")

[Company painting](/wiki/Company_painting "Company painting") depicting an
official of the East India Company, c. 1760

In the following decades there was a constant battle between the company lobby
and the Parliament. The company sought a permanent establishment, while the
Parliament would not willingly allow it greater autonomy and so relinquish the
opportunity to exploit the company's profits. In 1712, another act renewed the
status of the company, though the debts were repaid. By 1720, 15% of British
imports were from India, almost all passing through the company, which
reasserted the influence of the company lobby. The licence was prolonged until
1766 by yet another act in 1730.

At this time, Britain and France became bitter rivals. Frequent skirmishes
between them took place for control of colonial possessions. In 1742, fearing
the monetary consequences of a war, the British government agreed to extend
the deadline for the licensed exclusive trade by the company in India until
1783, in return for a further loan of £1 million. Between 1756 and 1763, the
[Seven Years' War](/wiki/Seven_Years%27_War "Seven Years' War") diverted the
state's attention towards consolidation and [defence of its territorial
possessions](/wiki/French_and_Indian_War "French and Indian War") in Europe
and its [colonies in North America](/wiki/English_colonization_of_the_Americas
"English colonization of the Americas").[25]

The war took place on Indian soil, between the company troops and the French
forces. In 1757, the [Law Officers of the
Crown](/wiki/Law_Officers_of_the_Crown "Law Officers of the Crown") delivered
the [Pratt-Yorke opinion](/wiki/Pratt-Yorke_opinion "Pratt-Yorke opinion")
distinguishing overseas territories acquired by [right of
conquest](/wiki/Right_of_conquest "Right of conquest") from those acquired by
private [treaty](/wiki/Treaty "Treaty"). The opinion asserted that, while the
Crown of Great Britain enjoyed sovereignty over both, only the property of the
former was vested in the Crown.[25]

With the advent of the [Industrial Revolution](/wiki/Industrial_Revolution
"Industrial Revolution"), Britain surged ahead of its European rivals. Demand
for Indian commodities was boosted by the need to sustain the troops and the
economy during the war, and by the increased availability of raw materials and
efficient methods of production. As home to the revolution, Britain
experienced higher standards of living. Its spiralling cycle of prosperity,
demand and production had a profound influence on overseas trade. The company
became the single largest player in the British global market. [William Henry
Pyne](/wiki/William_Henry_Pyne "William Henry Pyne") notes in his book _The
Microcosm of London_ (1808) that:

> On the 1 March 1801, the debts of the East India Company to £5,393,989 their
> effects to £15,404,736 and their sales increased since February 1793, from
> £4,988,300 to £7,602,041.

### Saltpetre
trade[[edit](/w/index.php?title=East_India_Company&action=edit&section=9 "Edit
section: Saltpetre trade")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Potassium_nitrate.jpg/220px-
Potassium_nitrate.jpg)](/wiki/File:Potassium_nitrate.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Potassium_nitrate.jpg "Enlarge")

[Saltpetre](/wiki/Saltpetre "Saltpetre") used for [gunpowder](/wiki/Gunpowder
"Gunpowder") was one of the major trade goods of the company.

Sir [John Banks](/wiki/Sir_John_Banks,_1st_Baronet "Sir John Banks, 1st
Baronet"), a businessman from [Kent](/wiki/Kent "Kent") who negotiated an
agreement between the king and the company, began his career in a syndicate
arranging contracts for [victualling the navy](/wiki/Victualling_Commissioners
"Victualling Commissioners"), an interest he kept up for most of his life. He
knew that [Samuel Pepys](/wiki/Samuel_Pepys "Samuel Pepys") and [John
Evelyn](/wiki/John_Evelyn "John Evelyn") had amassed a substantial fortune
from the [Levant](/wiki/Levant "Levant") and Indian trades.

He became a Director and later, as Governor of the East India Company in 1672,
he arranged a contract which included a loan of £20,000 and £30,000 worth of
[saltpetre](/wiki/Saltpetre "Saltpetre")—also known as potassium nitrate, a
primary ingredient in [gunpowder](/wiki/Gunpowder "Gunpowder")—for the King
"at the price it shall [sell by the candle](/wiki/Candle_auction "Candle
auction")"—that is by auction—where bidding could continue as long as an inch-
long candle remained alight.[26]

Outstanding debts were also agreed and the company permitted to export 250
tons of saltpetre. Again in 1673, Banks successfully negotiated another
contract for 700 tons of saltpetre at £37,000 between the king and the
company. So urgent was the need to supply the armed forces in the United
Kingdom, America and elsewhere that the authorities sometimes turned a blind
eye on the untaxed sales. One governor of the company was even reported as
saying in 1864 that he would rather have the saltpetre made than the tax on
salt.[27]

monopoly[[edit](/w/index.php?title=East_India_Company&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Basis for the monopoly")]

### Colonial
monopoly[[edit](/w/index.php?title=East_India_Company&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Colonial monopoly")]

Further information: [Great Britain in the Seven Years'
War](/wiki/Great_Britain_in_the_Seven_Years%27_War "Great Britain in the Seven
Years' War")

"Enlarge")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Clive.jpg/170px-
Clive.jpg)](/wiki/File:Clive.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Clive.jpg "Enlarge")

[Robert Clive](/wiki/Robert_Clive "Robert Clive") became the first British
[Governor of Bengal](/wiki/Governor_of_Bengal "Governor of Bengal") after he
had instated [Mir Jafar](/wiki/Mir_Jafar "Mir Jafar") as the [Nawab of
Bengal](/wiki/Nawab_of_Bengal "Nawab of Bengal").

The Seven Years' War (1756–63) resulted in the defeat of the French forces,
limited French imperial ambitions, and stunted the influence of the Industrial
Revolution in French territories. [Robert Clive](/wiki/Robert_Clive "Robert
Clive"), the Governor General, led the company to a victory against [Joseph
François Dupleix](/wiki/Joseph_Fran%C3%A7ois_Dupleix "Joseph François
Dupleix"), the commander of the French forces in India, and recaptured Fort St
George from the French. The company took this respite to seize
[Manila](/wiki/Battle_of_Manila_\(1762\) "Battle of Manila \(1762\)") in
1762.[28][_[better source needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:NOTRS "Wikipedia:NOTRS")_]

By the [Treaty of Paris](/wiki/Treaty_of_Paris_\(1763\) "Treaty of Paris
\(1763\)"), France regained the five establishments captured by the British
during the war ([Pondichéry](/wiki/Pondicherry_district "Pondicherry
district"), [Mahe](/wiki/Mah%C3%A9,_India "Mahé, India"),
[Karikal](/wiki/Karikal "Karikal"), [Yanam](/wiki/Yanam,_French_India "Yanam,
French India") and [Chandernagar](/wiki/Chandernagar "Chandernagar")) but was
prevented from erecting fortifications and keeping troops in Bengal (art. XI).
Elsewhere in India, the French were to remain a military threat, particularly
during the War of American Independence, and up to the capture of Pondichéry
in 1793 at the outset of the French Revolutionary Wars without any military
presence. Although these small outposts remained French possessions for the
next two hundred years, French ambitions on Indian territories were
effectively laid to rest, thus eliminating a major source of economic
competition for the company.

### East India Company Army and
Navy[[edit](/w/index.php?title=East_India_Company&action=edit&section=12 "Edit
section: East India Company Army and Navy")]

Main article: [Presidency armies](/wiki/Presidency_armies "Presidency armies")

Main article: [Company rule in India](/wiki/Company_rule_in_India "Company
rule in India")

In its first century and half, the EIC used a few hundred soldiers as guards.
The great expansion came after 1750, when it had 3000 regular troops. By 1763,
it had 26,000; by 1778, it had 67,000. It recruited largely [Indian
troops](/wiki/Sepoy "Sepoy"), and trained them along European lines.[29] The
military arm of the East India Company quickly developed to become a private
corporate armed force, and was used as an instrument of geo-political power
and expansion, rather than its original purpose as a guard force, and became
the most powerful military force in the Indian sub-continent. As it increased
in size the army was broken into the [Presidency
Armies](/wiki/Presidency_Armies "Presidency Armies") of
[Bengal](/wiki/Bengal_Army "Bengal Army"), [Madras](/wiki/Madras_Army "Madras
Army") and [Bombay](/wiki/Bombay_Army "Bombay Army") each recruiting their own
integral infantry, cavalry, artillery and horse artillery
[units](/wiki/Category:Honourable_East_India_Company_regiments
"Category:Honourable East India Company regiments"). The navy also grew
significantly, vastly expanding its
[fleet](/wiki/Category:Ships_of_the_British_East_India_Company "Category:Ships
of the British East India Company") and although made up predominantly of
heavily armed merchant vessels, called East Indiamen, it also included
warships.

#### Expansion and
Conquest[[edit](/w/index.php?title=East_India_Company&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Expansion and Conquest")]

The company, fresh from a colossal victory, and with the backing of its own
private well-disciplined and experienced army, was able to assert its
interests in the [Carnatic region](/wiki/Carnatic_\(region\) "Carnatic
\(region\)") from its base at [Madras](/wiki/Madras "Madras") and in Bengal
from Calcutta, without facing any further obstacles from other colonial
powers.[30]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/Shah_Alam_II%2C_1790s.jpg/170px-
Shah_Alam_II%2C_1790s.jpg)](/wiki/File:Shah_Alam_II,_1790s.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Shah_Alam_II,_1790s.jpg "Enlarge")

The Mughal Emperor [Shah Alam II](/wiki/Shah_Alam_II "Shah Alam II"), who with
his allies fought against the East India Company during his early years
(1760–64), only accepting the protection of the British in the year 1803,
after he had been blinded by his enemies and deserted by his subjects

It continued to experience resistance from local rulers during its expansion.
Robert Clive led company forces against [Siraj Ud
Daulah](/wiki/Siraj_Ud_Daulah "Siraj Ud Daulah"), the last independent
[Nawab](/wiki/Nawab "Nawab") of Bengal, [Bihar](/wiki/Bihar "Bihar"), and
Midnapore district in Odisha to victory at the [Battle of
Plassey](/wiki/Battle_of_Plassey "Battle of Plassey") in 1757, resulting in
the conquest of Bengal. This victory estranged the British and the Mughals,
since Siraj Ud Daulah was a Mughal feudatory ally.

With the gradual weakening of the [Marathas](/wiki/Maratha "Maratha") in the
aftermath of the three [Anglo-Maratha wars](/wiki/Anglo-Maratha_wars "Anglo-
Maratha wars"), the British also secured the Ganges-Jumna Doab, the Delhi-Agra
region, parts of Bundelkhand, Broach, some districts of Gujarat, the fort of
Ahmmadnagar, [province of Cuttack](/wiki/Cuttack_district "Cuttack district")
(which included Mughalbandi/the coastal part of [Odisha](/wiki/Odisha
"Odisha"), Garjat/the princely states of Odisha, [Balasore](/wiki/Balasore
"Balasore") Port, parts of [Midnapore](/wiki/Midnapore "Midnapore") district
of West Bengal), Bombay ([Mumbai](/wiki/Mumbai "Mumbai")) and the surrounding
areas, leading to a formal end of the Maratha empire and firm establishment of
the British East India Company in India.

[Hyder Ali](/wiki/Hyder_Ali "Hyder Ali") and [Tipu Sultan](/wiki/Tipu_Sultan
"Tipu Sultan"), the rulers of the [Kingdom of Mysore](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Mysore
"Kingdom of Mysore"), offered much resistance to the British forces. Having
sided with the French during the Revolutionary War, the rulers of Mysore
continued their struggle against the company with the four [Anglo-Mysore
Wars](/wiki/Anglo-Mysore_Wars "Anglo-Mysore Wars"). Mysore finally fell to the
company forces in 1799, in the fourth Anglo-Mysore war during which Tipu
Sultan was killed.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/2-12th_Madras_Native_Infantry_at_the_Battle_of_Assaye%2C_1803._Painting_by_JC_Stadler_%281780-1822%29%2C_c._1815..jpg/220px-2-12th_Madras_Native_Infantry_at_the_Battle_of_Assaye%2C_1803._Painting_by_JC_Stadler_%281780-1822%29%2C_c._1815..jpg)](/wiki/File:2-12th_Madras_Native_Infantry_at_the_Battle_of_Assaye,_1803._Painting_by_JC_Stadler_\(1780-1822\),_c._1815..jpg)

[](/wiki/File:2-12th_Madras_Native_Infantry_at_the_Battle_of_Assaye,_1803._Painting_by_JC_Stadler_\(1780-1822\),_c._1815..jpg
"Enlarge")

[Battle of Assaye](/wiki/Battle_of_Assaye "Battle of Assaye") during the
[Second Anglo-Maratha War](/wiki/Second_Anglo-Maratha_War "Second Anglo-
Maratha War"). Company replaced the Marathas as Mughal's protectors after the
second Anglo-Maratha war.[31]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Tipu_death.jpg/220px-
Tipu_death.jpg)](/wiki/File:Tipu_death.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Tipu_death.jpg "Enlarge")

The fall of [Tipu Sultan](/wiki/Tipu_Sultan "Tipu Sultan") and the [Sultanate
of Mysore](/wiki/Sultanate_of_Mysore "Sultanate of Mysore"), during the
[Battle of Seringapatam](/wiki/Battle_of_Seringapatam "Battle of
Seringapatam") in 1799

The last vestiges of local administration were restricted to the northern
regions of Delhi, [Oudh](/wiki/Oudh "Oudh"), [Rajputana](/wiki/Rajputana
"Rajputana"), and [Punjab](/wiki/Punjab_region "Punjab region"), where the
company's presence was ever increasing amidst infighting and offers of
protection among the remaining princes. The hundred years from the Battle of
Plassey in 1757 to the [Indian Rebellion of
1857](/wiki/Indian_Rebellion_of_1857 "Indian Rebellion of 1857") were a period
of consolidation for the company, during which it seized control of the entire
Indian subcontinent and functioned more as an administrator and less as a
trading concern.

A [cholera](/wiki/Cholera "Cholera") pandemic began in Bengal, then spread
across India by 1820. 10,000 British troops and countless Indians died during
this pandemic.[32] Between 1760 and 1834 only some 10% of the East India
Company's officers survived to take the final voyage home.[33]

In the early 19th century the Indian question of
[geopolitical](/wiki/Geopolitical "Geopolitical") dominance and empire holding
remained with the East India Company.[34] The three independent armies of the
company's Presidencies, with some locally raised irregular forces, expanded to
a total of 280,000 men by 1857.[35] First recruited from mercenaries and low-
caste volunteers, the [Bengal Army](/wiki/Bengal_Army "Bengal Army")
especially eventually became composed largely of high-caste Hindus and
landowning Muslims.

Within the Army, British officers who initially trained at the company's own
academy at the [Addiscombe Military
Seminary](/wiki/Addiscombe_Military_Seminary "Addiscombe Military Seminary"),
always outranked Indians, no matter how long their service. The highest rank
to which an Indian soldier could aspire was Subadar-Major (or Rissaldar-Major
in cavalry units), effectively a senior [subaltern](/wiki/Subaltern
"Subaltern") equivalent. Promotion for both British and Indian soldiers was
strictly by seniority, so Indian soldiers rarely reached the commissioned
ranks of Jamadar or Subadar before they were middle aged at best. They
received no training in administration or leadership to make them independent
of their British officers.

During the wars against the French and their allies in the late eighteenth and
early nineteenth centuries, the East India Company's armies were used to seize
the colonial possessions of other European nations, including the islands of
[Réunion](/wiki/R%C3%A9union "Réunion") and [Mauritius](/wiki/Mauritius
"Mauritius").

There was a systemic disrespect in the company for the spreading of
[Protestantism](/wiki/Protestantism "Protestantism") although it fostered
respect for [Hindu](/wiki/Hindu "Hindu") and [Muslim](/wiki/Muslim "Muslim"),
[castes](/wiki/Caste "Caste") and ethnic groups. The growth of tensions
between the EIC and the local religious and cultural groups grew in the 19th
century as the Protestant revival grew in Great Britain. These tensions
erupted at the Indian Rebellion of 1857 and the company ceased to exist when
the company dissolved through the [East India Stock Dividend Redemption Act
1873](/wiki/East_India_Stock_Dividend_Redemption_Act_1873 "East India Stock
Dividend Redemption Act 1873").[36]

### Opium
trade[[edit](/w/index.php?title=East_India_Company&action=edit&section=14
"Edit section: Opium trade")]

Main articles: [First Opium War](/wiki/First_Opium_War "First Opium War"),
[Second Opium War](/wiki/Second_Opium_War "Second Opium War"), and [History of
opium in China](/wiki/History_of_opium_in_China "History of opium in China")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/Destroying_Chinese_war_junks%2C_by_E._Duncan_%281843%29.jpg/220px-
Destroying_Chinese_war_junks%2C_by_E._Duncan_%281843%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Destroying_Chinese_war_junks,_by_E._Duncan_\(1843\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Destroying_Chinese_war_junks,_by_E._Duncan_\(1843\).jpg
"Enlarge")

The _[Nemesis](/wiki/Nemesis_\(1839\) "Nemesis \(1839\)")_ destroying Chinese
war [junks](/wiki/Junk_\(ship\) "Junk \(ship\)") during the [Second Battle of
Chuenpi](/wiki/Second_Battle_of_Chuenpi "Second Battle of Chuenpi"), 7 January
1841, by [Edward Duncan](/wiki/Edward_Duncan "Edward Duncan")

In the 18th century, Britain had a huge trade deficit with [Qing
dynasty](/wiki/Qing_dynasty "Qing dynasty") China and so, in 1773, the company
created a British monopoly on [opium](/wiki/Opium "Opium") buying in
[Bengal](/wiki/Bengal "Bengal"), India by prohibiting the licensing of opium
farmers and private cultivation. The monopoly system established in 1799
continued with minimal changes until 1947.[37] As the [opium
trade](/wiki/Opium_trade "Opium trade") was illegal in China, Company ships
could not carry opium to China. So the opium produced in Bengal was sold in
Calcutta on condition that it be sent to China.[38]

Despite the Chinese ban on opium imports, reaffirmed in 1799 by the [Jiaqing
Emperor](/wiki/Jiaqing_Emperor "Jiaqing Emperor"), the drug was smuggled into
China from Bengal by traffickers and agency houses such as [Jardine, Matheson
& Co](/wiki/Jardine_Matheson_Holdings "Jardine Matheson Holdings") and [Dent &
Co.](/wiki/Dent_%26_Co. "Dent & Co.") in amounts averaging 900 tons a year.
The proceeds of the drug-smugglers landing their cargoes at [Lintin
Island](/wiki/Lintin_Island "Lintin Island") were paid into the company's
factory at [Canton](/wiki/Guangzhou "Guangzhou") and by 1825, most of the
money needed to buy tea in China was raised by the illegal opium trade.

The company established a group of trading settlements centred on the Straits
of Malacca called the [Straits Settlements](/wiki/Straits_Settlements "Straits
Settlements") in 1826 to protect its trade route to China and to combat local
piracy. The settlements were also used as penal settlements for Indian
civilian and military prisoners.

In 1838 with the amount of smuggled opium entering China approaching 1,400
tons a year, the Chinese imposed a death penalty for opium smuggling and sent
a Special Imperial Commissioner, [Lin Zexu](/wiki/Lin_Zexu "Lin Zexu"), to
curb smuggling. This resulted in the [First Opium War](/wiki/First_Opium_War
"First Opium War") (1839–42). After the war Hong Kong island was ceded to
Britain under the [Treaty of Nanking](/wiki/Treaty_of_Nanking "Treaty of
Nanking") and the Chinese market opened to the opium traders of Britain and
other nations.[37] The Jardines and [Apcar and
Company](/wiki/Apcar_and_Company "Apcar and Company") dominated the trade,
although [P&O](/wiki/Peninsular_and_Oriental_Steam_Navigation_Company
"Peninsular and Oriental Steam Navigation Company") also tried to take a
share.[39] A [Second Opium War](/wiki/Second_Opium_War "Second Opium War")
fought by Britain and France against China lasted from 1856 until 1860 and led
to the [Treaty of Tientsin](/wiki/Treaty_of_Tientsin "Treaty of Tientsin"),
which legalised the importation of opium. Legalisation stimulated domestic
Chinese opium production and increased the importation of opium from Turkey
and Persia. This increased competition for the Chinese market led to India's
reducing its opium output and diversifying its exports.[37]

###
Writers[[edit](/w/index.php?title=East_India_Company&action=edit&section=16
"Edit section: Writers")]

[![Two ships in a harbour, one in the distance. On board, men stripped to the
waist and wearing feathers in their hair are throwing crates overboard. A

[](/wiki/File:Boston_Tea_Party_Currier_colored.jpg "Enlarge")

_The Destruction of Tea at Boston Harbor_ , 1773

The company employed many junior clerks, known as "writers", to record the
details of accounting, managerial decisions, and activities related to the
company, such as minutes of meetings, copies of Company orders and contracts,
and filings of reports and copies of ship's logs. Several well-known British
scholars and literary men had Company writerships, such as [Henry Thomas
Colebrooke](/wiki/Henry_Thomas_Colebrooke "Henry Thomas Colebrooke") in India
and [Charles Lamb](/wiki/Charles_Lamb "Charles Lamb") in England.

### Financial
troubles[[edit](/w/index.php?title=East_India_Company&action=edit&section=17
"Edit section: Financial troubles")]

Though the company was becoming increasingly bold and ambitious in putting
down resisting states, it was becoming clearer that the company was incapable
of governing the vast expanse of the captured territories. The [Bengal famine
of 1770](/wiki/Bengal_famine_of_1770 "Bengal famine of 1770"), in which one-
third of the local population died, caused distress in Britain. Military and
administrative costs mounted beyond control in British-administered regions in
Bengal because of the ensuing drop in labour productivity.

At the same time, there was commercial stagnation and trade depression
throughout Europe. The directors of the company attempted to avert bankruptcy
by appealing to Parliament for financial help. This led to the passing of the
[Tea Act](/wiki/Tea_Act "Tea Act") in 1773, which gave the company greater
autonomy in running its trade in the American colonies, and allowed it an
exemption from tea import duties which its colonial competitors were required
to pay.

When the American colonists and tea merchants were told of this Act, they
boycotted the company tea. Although the price of tea had dropped because of
the Act, it also validated the [Townshend Acts](/wiki/Townshend_Acts
"Townshend Acts"), setting the precedent for the king to impose additional
taxes in the future. The arrival of tax-exempt Company tea, undercutting the
local merchants, triggered the [Boston Tea Party](/wiki/Boston_Tea_Party
"Boston Tea Party") in the [Province of Massachusetts
Bay](/wiki/Province_of_Massachusetts_Bay "Province of Massachusetts Bay"), one
of the major events leading up to the [American
Revolution](/wiki/American_Revolution "American Revolution").

### Regulating Acts of
Parliament[[edit](/w/index.php?title=East_India_Company&action=edit&section=18
"Edit section: Regulating Acts of Parliament")]

#### East India Company Act
1773[[edit](/w/index.php?title=East_India_Company&action=edit&section=19 "Edit
section: East India Company Act 1773")]

By the [Regulating Act of 1773](/wiki/Regulating_Act_of_1773 "Regulating Act
of 1773") (later known as the East India Company Act 1773), the [Parliament of
Great Britain](/wiki/Parliament_of_Great_Britain "Parliament of Great
Britain") imposed a series of administrative and economic reforms; this
clearly established Parliament's sovereignty and ultimate control over the
company. The Act recognised the company's political functions and clearly
established that the "[acquisition of
sovereignty](/wiki/Acquisition_of_sovereignty "Acquisition of sovereignty") by
the subjects of the Crown is on behalf of the Crown and not in its own right".

Despite stiff resistance from the East India lobby in parliament and from the
company's shareholders, the Act passed. It introduced substantial governmental
control and allowed British India to be formally under the control of the
Crown, but leased back to the company at £40,000 for two years. Under the
Act's most important provision, a governing Council composed of five members
was created in Calcutta. The three members nominated by Parliament and
representing the Government's interest could, and invariably would, outvote
the two Company members. The Council was headed by [Warren
Hastings](/wiki/Warren_Hastings "Warren Hastings"), the incumbent Governor,
who became the first [Governor-General of Bengal](/wiki/Governor-
General_of_Bengal "Governor-General of Bengal"), with an ill-defined authority
over the Bombay and Madras Presidencies.[40] His nomination, made by the Court
of Directors, would in future be subject to the approval of a [Council of
Four](/wiki/Council_of_Four_from_India "Council of Four from India") appointed
by the Crown. Initially, the Council consisted of [Lt. General Sir John
Clavering](/wiki/John_Clavering_\(British_Army_officer\) "John Clavering
\(British Army officer\)"), [The Honourable Sir George
Monson](/wiki/George_Monson "George Monson"), [Sir Richard
Barwell](/wiki/Richard_Barwell "Richard Barwell"), and [Sir Philip
Francis](/wiki/Philip_Francis_\(English_politician\) "Philip Francis \(English
politician\)").[41]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Nawab_Mubarak_al-
Daula_of_Murshidabad_%281770-93%29_enthroned_in_durbar.jpg/220px-
Nawab_Mubarak_al-
Daula_of_Murshidabad_%281770-93%29_enthroned_in_durbar.jpg)](/wiki/File:Nawab_Mubarak_al-
Daula_of_Murshidabad_\(1770-93\)_enthroned_in_durbar.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Nawab_Mubarak_al-
Daula_of_Murshidabad_\(1770-93\)_enthroned_in_durbar.jpg "Enlarge")

Nawab [Mubarak Ali Khan](/wiki/Mubarak_Ali_Khan_\(Nawab_of_Bengal\) "Mubarak
Ali Khan \(Nawab of Bengal\)") with his son in the Nawab's
_[Durbar](/wiki/Durbar_\(court\) "Durbar \(court\)")_ with [British
Resident](/wiki/British_Resident "British Resident"), [Sir John
Hadley](/wiki/Sir_John_D%27Oyly,_6th_Baronet "Sir John D'Oyly, 6th Baronet")

Hastings was entrusted with the power of peace and war. British judges and
magistrates would also be sent to India to administer the legal system. The
Governor General and the council would have complete legislative powers. The
company was allowed to maintain its virtual monopoly over trade in exchange
for the biennial sum and was obligated to export a minimum quantity of goods
yearly to Britain. The costs of administration were to be met by the company.
The company initially welcomed these provisions, but the annual burden of the
payment contributed to the steady decline of its finances.[41]

#### East India Company Act 1784 (Pitt's India
Act)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=East_India_Company&action=edit&section=20 "Edit
section: East India Company Act 1784 \(Pitt's India Act\)")]

The East India Company Act 1784 ([Pitt's India Act](/wiki/Pitt%27s_India_Act
"Pitt's India Act")) had two key aspects:

  * Relationship to the British government: the bill differentiated the East India Company's political functions from its commercial activities. In political matters the East India Company was subordinated to the British government directly. To accomplish this, the Act created a [Board of Commissioners for the Affairs of India](/wiki/India_Board "India Board"), usually referred to as the Board of Control. The members of the Board were the [Chancellor of the Exchequer](/wiki/Chancellor_of_the_Exchequer "Chancellor of the Exchequer"), the [Secretary of State](/wiki/Secretary_of_State_\(United_Kingdom\) "Secretary of State \(United Kingdom\)"), and four [Privy Councillors](/wiki/Privy_Council_of_the_United_Kingdom "Privy Council of the United Kingdom"), nominated by the King. The act specified that the Secretary of State "shall preside at, and be [President of the said Board](/wiki/President_of_the_Board_of_Control "President of the Board of Control")".
  * Internal Administration of British India: the bill laid the foundation for the centralised and bureaucratic British administration of India which would reach its peak at the beginning of the 20th century during the governor-generalship of [George Nathaniel Curzon, 1st Baron Curzon](/wiki/George_Nathaniel_Curzon,_1st_Marquess_Curzon_of_Kedleston "George Nathaniel Curzon, 1st Marquess Curzon of Kedleston").

Pitt's Act was deemed a failure because it quickly became apparent that the
boundaries between government control and the company's powers were nebulous
and highly subjective. The government felt obliged to respond to humanitarian
calls for better treatment of local peoples in British-occupied territories.
[Edmund Burke](/wiki/Edmund_Burke "Edmund Burke"), a former East India Company
shareholder and diplomat, was moved to address the situation and introduced a
new Regulating Bill in 1783. The bill was defeated amid lobbying by company
loyalists and accusations of nepotism in the bill's recommendations for the
appointment of councillors.

#### Act of
1786[[edit](/w/index.php?title=East_India_Company&action=edit&section=21 "Edit
section: Act of 1786")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Surrender_of_Tipu_Sultan.jpg/220px-
Surrender_of_Tipu_Sultan.jpg)](/wiki/File:Surrender_of_Tipu_Sultan.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Surrender_of_Tipu_Sultan.jpg "Enlarge")

General [Lord Cornwallis](/wiki/Charles_Cornwallis,_1st_Marquess_Cornwallis
"Charles Cornwallis, 1st Marquess Cornwallis"), receiving two of [Tipu
Sultan](/wiki/Tipu_Sultan "Tipu Sultan")'s sons as hostages in the year 1793

The Act of 1786 (26 Geo. 3 c. 16) enacted the demand of [Earl
Cornwallis](/wiki/Charles_Cornwallis,_1st_Marquess_Cornwallis "Charles
Cornwallis, 1st Marquess Cornwallis") that the powers of the Governor-General
be enlarged to empower him, in special cases, to override the majority of his
Council and act on his own special responsibility. The Act enabled the offices
of the Governor-General and the Commander-in-Chief to be jointly held by the
same official.

This Act clearly demarcated borders between the Crown and the company. After
this point, the company functioned as a regularised subsidiary of the Crown,
with greater accountability for its actions and reached a stable stage of
expansion and consolidation. Having temporarily achieved a state of truce with
the Crown, the company continued to expand its influence to nearby territories
through threats and coercive actions. By the middle of the 19th century, the
company's rule extended across most of India, [Burma](/wiki/Burma "Burma"),
[Malaya](/wiki/British_Malaya "British Malaya"), Singapore, and [British Hong
Kong](/wiki/British_Hong_Kong "British Hong Kong"), and a fifth of the world's
population was under its trading influence. In addition, [Penang](/wiki/Penang
"Penang"), one of the states in Malaya, became the fourth most important
settlement, a presidency, of the company's Indian territories.[42]

#### East India Company Act 1793 (Charter
Act)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=East_India_Company&action=edit&section=22 "Edit
section: East India Company Act 1793 \(Charter Act\)")]

The company's charter was renewed for a further 20 years by the [Charter Act
of 1793](/wiki/Charter_Act_of_1793 "Charter Act of 1793"). In contrast with
the legislative proposals of the previous two decades, the 1793 Act was not a
particularly controversial measure, and made only minimal changes to the
system of government in India and to British oversight of the company's
activities.

#### East India Company Act 1813 (Charter
Act)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=East_India_Company&action=edit&section=23 "Edit
section: East India Company Act 1813 \(Charter Act\)")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/Major-
General_the_Hon._Arthur_Wellesley_being_received_in_durbar_at_the_Chepauk_Palace_Madras_by_Azim_al-
Daula_Nawab_of_the_Carnatic_18th_February_1805.jpg/220px-Major-
General_the_Hon._Arthur_Wellesley_being_received_in_durbar_at_the_Chepauk_Palace_Madras_by_Azim_al-
Daula_Nawab_of_the_Carnatic_18th_February_1805.jpg)](/wiki/File:Major-
General_the_Hon._Arthur_Wellesley_being_received_in_durbar_at_the_Chepauk_Palace_Madras_by_Azim_al-
Daula_Nawab_of_the_Carnatic_18th_February_1805.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Major-
General_the_Hon._Arthur_Wellesley_being_received_in_durbar_at_the_Chepauk_Palace_Madras_by_Azim_al-
Daula_Nawab_of_the_Carnatic_18th_February_1805.jpg "Enlarge")

[Major-General Wellesley](/wiki/Arthur_Wellesley,_1st_Duke_of_Wellington
"Arthur Wellesley, 1st Duke of Wellington"), meeting with [Nawab](/wiki/Nawab
"Nawab") Azim al-Daula, 1805

The aggressive policies of [Lord
Wellesley](/wiki/Richard_Wellesley,_1st_Marquess_Wellesley "Richard Wellesley,
1st Marquess Wellesley") and [the Marquess of Hastings](/wiki/Francis_Rawdon-
Hastings,_1st_Marquess_of_Hastings "Francis Rawdon-Hastings, 1st Marquess of
Hastings") led to the company's gaining control of all India (except for the
Punjab and Sindh), and some part of the then kingdom of Nepal under the
[Sugauli Treaty](/wiki/Sugauli_Treaty "Sugauli Treaty"). The Indian Princes
had become vassals of the company. But the expense of wars leading to the
total control of India strained the company's finances. The company was forced
to petition Parliament for assistance. This was the background to the [Charter
Act of 1813](/wiki/Charter_Act_of_1813 "Charter Act of 1813") which, among
other things:

  * asserted the sovereignty of the British Crown over the Indian territories held by the company;
  * renewed the charter of the company for a further twenty years, but 
    * deprived the company of its Indian trade monopoly except for trade in tea and the trade with China
    * required the company to maintain separate and distinct its commercial and territorial accounts
  * opened India to missionaries

#### Government of India Act
1833[[edit](/w/index.php?title=East_India_Company&action=edit&section=24 "Edit
section: Government of India Act 1833")]

[![1835 gold Double Mohur \(reverse\), valued at 30
Rupees](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/India_1835_2_Mohurs.jpg/500px-
India_1835_2_Mohurs.jpg)](/wiki/File:India_1835_2_Mohurs.jpg)

[File:India 1835 2 Mohurs.jpg](/wiki/File:India_1835_2_Mohurs.jpg "File:India
1835 2 Mohurs.jpg")

1835 gold Double [Mohur](/wiki/Mohur "Mohur") (reverse), valued at 30
[Rupees](/wiki/Rupee "Rupee")

The Industrial Revolution in Britain, the consequent search for markets, and
the rise of _[laissez-faire](/wiki/Laissez-faire "Laissez-faire")_ economic
ideology form the background to the [Government of India Act
1833](/wiki/Saint_Helena_Act_1833 "Saint Helena Act 1833") (3 & 4 Will. 4 c.
85). The Act:

  * removed the company's remaining trade monopolies and divested it of all its commercial functions
  * renewed for another twenty years the company's political and administrative authority
  * invested the Board of Control with full power and authority over the company. As stated by Professor Sri Ram Sharma,[43] "The President of the Board of Control now became Minister for Indian Affairs."
  * carried further the ongoing process of administrative centralisation through investing the Governor-General in Council with, full power and authority to superintend and, control the Presidency Governments in all civil and military matters
  * initiated a machinery for the codification of laws
  * provided that no Indian subject of the company would be debarred from holding any office under the company by reason of his religion, place of birth, descent or colour
  * vested the Island of [St Helena](/wiki/St_Helena "St Helena") in the Crown[44]

British influence continued to expand; in 1845, Great Britain purchased the
Danish colony of [Tranquebar](/wiki/Tranquebar "Tranquebar"). The company had
at various stages extended its influence to China, the Philippines, and
[Java](/wiki/Java_island "Java island"). It had solved its critical lack of
cash needed to buy tea by exporting Indian-grown opium to China. China's
efforts to end the trade led to the First Opium War (1839–1842).

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/Charles_D%27Oyly00.jpg/220px-
Charles_D%27Oyly00.jpg)](/wiki/File:Charles_D%27Oyly00.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Charles_D%27Oyly00.jpg "Enlarge")

View of the Calcutta port in 1848

#### English Education Act
1835[[edit](/w/index.php?title=East_India_Company&action=edit&section=25 "Edit
section: English Education Act 1835")]

Main article: [English Education Act 1835](/wiki/English_Education_Act_1835
"English Education Act 1835")

The English Education Act by the Council of India in 1835 reallocated funds
from the East India Company to spend on education and literature in India.

#### Government of India Act
1853[[edit](/w/index.php?title=East_India_Company&action=edit&section=26 "Edit
section: Government of India Act 1853")]

This Act (16 & 17 Vict. c. 95) provided that British India would remain under
the administration of the company in trust for the Crown until Parliament
should decide otherwise. It also introduced a system of open competition as
the basis of recruitment for civil servants of the company and thus deprived
the Directors of their patronage system.[45]

Under the act, for the first time the legislative and executive powers of the
governor general's council were separated. It also added six additional
members to the governor general's executive committee.[46]

## Indian Rebellion and
disestablishment[[edit](/w/index.php?title=East_India_Company&action=edit&section=27
"Edit section: Indian Rebellion and disestablishment")]

Main article: [Indian Rebellion of 1857](/wiki/Indian_Rebellion_of_1857
"Indian Rebellion of 1857")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d0/%22Capture_of_the_King_of_Delhi_by_Captain_Hodson%22.jpg/220px-%22Capture_of_the_King_of_Delhi_by_Captain_Hodson%22.jpg)](/wiki/File:%22Capture_of_the_King_of_Delhi_by_Captain_Hodson%22.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:%22Capture_of_the_King_of_Delhi_by_Captain_Hodson%22.jpg
"Enlarge")

Capture of the last Mughal emperor [Bahadur Shah
Zafar](/wiki/Bahadur_Shah_Zafar "Bahadur Shah Zafar") and his sons by [William
Hodson](/wiki/William_Stephen_Raikes_Hodson "William Stephen Raikes Hodson")
in 1857

The Indian Rebellion of 1857 (also known as the Indian Mutiny) resulted in
widespread devastation in India: many condemned the East India Company for
permitting the events to occur.[47] In the aftermath of the Rebellion, under
the provisions of the [Government of India Act
1858](/wiki/Government_of_India_Act_1858 "Government of India Act 1858"), the
British Government nationalised the company. [The Crown](/wiki/The_Crown "The
Crown") took over its Indian possessions, its administrative powers and
machinery, and its [armed forces](/wiki/Presidency_armies "Presidency
armies").

The company remained in existence in vestigial form, continuing to manage the
tea trade on behalf of the British Government (and the supply of [Saint
Helena](/wiki/Saint_Helena "Saint Helena")) until the [East India Stock
Dividend Redemption Act
1873](/wiki/East_India_Stock_Dividend_Redemption_Act_1873 "East India Stock
Dividend Redemption Act 1873") came into effect, on 1 January 1874. This Act
provided for the formal dissolution of the company on 1 June 1874, after a
final dividend payment and the commutation or redemption of its stock.[48]
_[The Times](/wiki/The_Times "The Times")_ commented on 8 April 1873:[49]

> It accomplished a work such as in the whole history of the human race no
> other trading Company ever attempted, and such as none, surely, is likely to
> attempt in the years to come.

## Establishments in
Britain[[edit](/w/index.php?title=East_India_Company&action=edit&section=28
"Edit section: Establishments in Britain")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/88/East_India_House_THS_1817_edited.jpg/220px-
East_India_House_THS_1817_edited.jpg)](/wiki/File:East_India_House_THS_1817_edited.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:East_India_House_THS_1817_edited.jpg "Enlarge")

The expanded [East India House](/wiki/East_India_House "East India House"),
Leadenhall Street, London, as reconstructed in 1796–1800. A drawing by [Thomas
Hosmer Shepherd](/wiki/Thomas_Hosmer_Shepherd "Thomas Hosmer Shepherd") of
c.1817.

The company's headquarters in London, from which much of India was governed,
was [East India House](/wiki/East_India_House "East India House") in
[Leadenhall Street](/wiki/Leadenhall_Street "Leadenhall Street"). After
occupying premises in [Philpot Lane](/wiki/Philpot_Lane "Philpot Lane") from
1600 to 1621; in [Crosby House](/wiki/Crosby_Hall,_London "Crosby Hall,
London"), [Bishopsgate](/wiki/Bishopsgate "Bishopsgate"), from 1621 to 1638;
and in Leadenhall Street from 1638 to 1648, the company moved into Craven
House, an Elizabethan mansion in Leadenhall Street. The building had become
known as East India House by 1661. It was completely rebuilt and enlarged in
1726–9; and further significantly remodelled and expanded in 1796–1800. It was
finally vacated in 1860 and demolished in 1861–62. The site is now occupied by
the [Lloyd's building](/wiki/Lloyd%27s_building "Lloyd's building").

In 1607, the company decided to build its own ships and leased a yard on the
[River Thames](/wiki/River_Thames "River Thames") at [Deptford](/wiki/Deptford
"Deptford"). By 1614, the yard having become too small, an alternative site
was acquired at [Blackwall](/wiki/Blackwall_Yard "Blackwall Yard"): the new
yard was fully operational by 1617. It was sold in 1656, although for some
years East India Company ships continued to be built and repaired there under
the new owners.

In 1803, an Act of Parliament, promoted by the East India Company, established
the East India Dock Company, with the aim of establishing a new set of docks
(the [East India Docks](/wiki/East_India_Docks "East India Docks")) primarily
for the use of ships trading with India. The existing Brunswick Dock, part of
the Blackwall Yard site, became the Export Dock; while a new Import Dock was
built to the north. In 1838 the East India Dock Company merged with the [West
India Dock Company](/wiki/West_India_Docks "West India Docks"). The docks were
taken over by the [Port of London Authority](/wiki/Port_of_London_Authority
"Port of London Authority") in 1909, and closed in 1967.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Addiscombe_Seminary_photo_c.1859.jpg/220px-
Addiscombe_Seminary_photo_c.1859.jpg)](/wiki/File:Addiscombe_Seminary_photo_c.1859.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Addiscombe_Seminary_photo_c.1859.jpg "Enlarge")

[Addiscombe Seminary](/wiki/Addiscombe_Military_Seminary "Addiscombe Military
Seminary"), photographed in _c_.1859, with cadets in the foreground

The [East India College](/wiki/East_India_Company_College "East India Company
College") was founded in 1806 as a training establishment for "writers" (i.e.
clerks) in the company's service. It was initially located in [Hertford
Castle](/wiki/Hertford_Castle "Hertford Castle"), but moved in 1809 to
purpose-built premises at [Hertford Heath](/wiki/Hertford_Heath "Hertford
Heath"), Hertfordshire. In 1858 the college closed; but in 1862 the buildings
reopened as a [public school](/wiki/Public_school_\(United_Kingdom\) "Public
school \(United Kingdom\)"), now [Haileybury and Imperial Service
College](/wiki/Haileybury_and_Imperial_Service_College "Haileybury and
Imperial Service College").

The [East India Company Military Seminary](/wiki/Addiscombe_Military_Seminary
"Addiscombe Military Seminary") was founded in 1809 at
[Addiscombe](/wiki/Addiscombe "Addiscombe"), near [Croydon](/wiki/Croydon
"Croydon"), Surrey, to train young officers for service in the company's
armies in India. It was based in Addiscombe Place, an early 18th-century
mansion. The government took it over in 1858, and renamed it the Royal Indian
Military College. In 1861 it was closed, and the site was subsequently
redeveloped.

In 1818, the company entered into an agreement by which those of its servants
who were certified insane in India might be cared for at Pembroke House,
[Hackney](/wiki/Hackney_\(parish\) "Hackney \(parish\)"), London, a private
[lunatic asylum](/wiki/History_of_psychiatric_institutions "History of
psychiatric institutions") run by Dr George Rees until 1838, and thereafter by
Dr William Williams. The arrangement outlasted the company itself, continuing
until 1870, when the India Office opened its own asylum, the Royal India
Asylum, at [Hanwell](/wiki/Hanwell "Hanwell"), Middlesex.[50]

The [East India Club](/wiki/East_India_Club "East India Club") in London was
formed in 1849 for officers of the company. The Club still exists today as a
private [gentlemen's club](/wiki/Gentlemen%27s_club "Gentlemen's club") with
its club house situated at 16 [St. James's Square](/wiki/St._James%27s_Square
"St. James's Square"), London.[51]

## Legacy and
criticisms[[edit](/w/index.php?title=East_India_Company&action=edit&section=29
"Edit section: Legacy and criticisms")]

[![\[icon\]](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg/20px-Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg) | **This section needs expansion**. You can help by [adding to it](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=East_India_Company&action=edit&section=). _(March 2015)_  
---|---  
  
The East India Company had a long lasting impact on the Indian Subcontinent,
with both positive and harmful effects. Although dissolved following the
[rebellion of 1857](/wiki/Indian_Rebellion_of_1857 "Indian Rebellion of
1857"), it stimulated the growth of the [British Empire](/wiki/British_Empire
"British Empire"). Its armies were to become the armies of British India after
1857, and it played a key role in introducing English as an official language
in India.

The East India Company was the first company to record the Chinese usage of
orange-flavoured tea, which led to the development of [Earl Grey
tea](/wiki/Earl_Grey_tea "Earl Grey tea").[52]

The East India Company introduced a system of merit-based appointments that
provided a model for the British and Indian civil service.[53]

Widespread corruption and looting of Bengal resources and treasures during its
rule resulted in poverty.[5] Famines, such as the [Great Bengal famine of
1770](/wiki/Great_Bengal_Famine "Great Bengal Famine") and [subsequent
famines](/wiki/Great_Bengal_Famine_of_1943 "Great Bengal Famine of 1943")
during the 18th and 19th centuries, became more widespread, chiefly because of
exploitative agriculture promulgated by the policies of the East India company
and the forced cultivation of [opium](/wiki/Opium "Opium") in place of
grain.[54][55]

[Macaulayism](/wiki/Macaulayism "Macaulayism") and the British education
system have been blamed for producing a generation of Indians not proud of
their distinct heritage.[56]
