1801–1874

The English East India Company flag changed with history, with a
[canton](/wiki/Canton_\(flag\) "Canton \(flag\)") based on the current flag of
the Kingdom, and a field of 9 to 13 alternating red and white stripes.

From the period of 1600, the canton consisted of a [St George's
Cross](/wiki/St_George%27s_Cross "St George's Cross") representing the
[Kingdom of England](/wiki/Kingdom_of_England "Kingdom of England"). With the
[Acts of Union 1707](/wiki/Acts_of_Union_1707 "Acts of Union 1707"), the
canton was updated to be the new [Union Flag](/wiki/Evolution_of_UK_Flag
"Evolution of UK Flag")—consisting of an English St George's Cross combined
with a Scottish [St Andrew's cross](/wiki/Flag_of_Scotland "Flag of
Scotland")—representing the [Kingdom of Great
Britain](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Great_Britain "Kingdom of Great Britain"). After the
[Acts of Union 1800](/wiki/Acts_of_Union_1800 "Acts of Union 1800") that
joined Ireland with Great Britain to form the United Kingdom, the canton of
the East India Company flag was altered accordingly to include a [Saint
Patrick's Saltire](/wiki/Saint_Patrick%27s_Saltire "Saint Patrick's Saltire")
replicating the updated [Union Flag](/wiki/Union_Flag "Union Flag")
representing the [United Kingdom of Great Britain and
Ireland](/wiki/United_Kingdom_of_Great_Britain_and_Ireland "United Kingdom of
Great Britain and Ireland").

Regarding the field of the flag, there has been much debate and discussion
regarding the number and order of the stripes. Historical documents and
paintings show many variations from 9 to 13 stripes, with some images showing
the top stripe's being red and others showing the top stripe being white.

At the time of the American Revolution the East India Company flag was nearly
identical to the [Grand Union Flag](/wiki/Grand_Union_Flag "Grand Union
Flag"). Historian [Charles Fawcett](/wiki/Charles_Fawcett_\(historian\)
"Charles Fawcett \(historian\)") argued that the East India Company Flag
inspired the [Stars and Stripes](/wiki/Flag_of_the_United_States "Flag of the
United States").[57]

### Coat of
arms[[edit](/w/index.php?title=East_India_Company&action=edit&section=32 "Edit
section: Coat of arms")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/23/Coat_of_arms_of_the_East_India_Company.svg/220px-
Coat_of_arms_of_the_East_India_Company.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Coat_of_arms_of_the_East_India_Company.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Coat_of_arms_of_the_East_India_Company.svg "Enlarge")

The later coat of arms of the East India Company

The East India Company's original [coat of arms](/wiki/Coat_of_arms "Coat of
arms") was granted in 1600. The arms was as follows:

"Azure, three ships with three masts, rigged and under full sail, the sails,
pennants and ensigns Argent, each charged with a cross Gules; on a chief of
the second a pale quarterly Azure and Gules, on the 1st and 4th a fleur-de-lis
or, on the 2nd and 3rd a leopard or, between two roses Gules seeded Or barbed
Vert." The shield had as a [crest](/wiki/Crest_\(heraldry\) "Crest
\(heraldry\)"): "A sphere without a frame, bounded with the Zodiac in bend Or,
between two pennants flottant Argent, each charged with a cross Gules, over
the sphere the words DEUS INDICAT" ([Latin](/wiki/Latin "Latin"): God
Indicates). The [supporters](/wiki/Supporter_\(heraldry\) "Supporter
\(heraldry\)") were two sea lions (lions with fishes' tails) and the
[motto](/wiki/Motto "Motto") was _DEO DUCENTE NIL NOCET_ (Latin: Where God
Leads, Nothing Harms).[58]

The East India Company's arms, granted in 1698, were: "Argent a cross Gules;
in the dexter chief quarter an escutcheon of the [arms of
France](/wiki/Coat_of_arms_of_France "Coat of arms of France") and
[England](/wiki/Coat_of_arms_of_England "Coat of arms of England") quarterly,
the shield ornamentally and regally crowned Or." The crest was: "A lion
rampant guardant Or holding between the forepaws a regal crown proper." The
supporters were: "Two lions rampant guardant Or, each supporting a banner
erect Argent, charged with a cross Gules." The motto was _AUSPICIO REGIS ET
SENATUS ANGLIÆ_ (Latin: Under the auspices of the King and the Senate of
England).[58]

### Merchant
mark[[edit](/w/index.php?title=East_India_Company&action=edit&section=33 "Edit
section: Merchant mark")]

  * [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/0/07/EIC_Coin_1791_Half_Pice.jpg/120px-EIC_Coin_1791_Half_Pice.jpg)](/wiki/File:EIC_Coin_1791_Half_Pice.jpg)

HEIC [Merchant's mark](/wiki/Merchant%27s_mark "Merchant's mark") on East
India Company Coin: 1791 Half Pice

  * [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b2/Symbols_on_a_Blue_Scinde_Dawk.jpg/120px-Symbols_on_a_Blue_Scinde_Dawk.jpg)](/wiki/File:Symbols_on_a_Blue_Scinde_Dawk.jpg)

HEIC [Merchant's mark](/wiki/Merchant%27s_mark "Merchant's mark") on a Blue
Scinde Dawk postage stamp (1852)

When the East India Company was chartered in 1600, it was still customary for
individual merchants or members of Companies such as the [Company of Merchant
Adventurers](/wiki/Company_of_Merchant_Adventurers_of_London "Company of
Merchant Adventurers of London") to have a distinguishing [merchant's
mark](/wiki/Merchant%27s_mark "Merchant's mark") which often included the
mystical "Sign of Four" and served as a trademark. The East India Company's
merchant mark consisted of a "Sign of Four" atop a heart within which was a
[saltire](/wiki/Saltire "Saltire") between the lower arms of which were the
initials "EIC". This mark was a central motif of the East India Company's
coinage[59] and forms the central emblem displayed on the [Scinde
Dawk](/wiki/Scinde_Dawk "Scinde Dawk") postage stamps.[60]

## Ships[[edit](/w/index.php?title=East_India_Company&action=edit&section=34
"Edit section: Ships")]

See also: [East Indiaman](/wiki/East_Indiaman "East Indiaman") and [List of
ports of call of the British East India
Company](/wiki/List_of_ports_of_call_of_the_British_East_India_Company "List
of ports of call of the British East India Company")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Ships_in_Bombay_Harbour%2C_1731.jpg/220px-
Ships_in_Bombay_Harbour%2C_1731.jpg)](/wiki/File:Ships_in_Bombay_Harbour,_1731.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Ships_in_Bombay_Harbour,_1731.jpg "Enlarge")

Ships in [Bombay Harbour](/wiki/Bombay_Harbour "Bombay Harbour"), c. 1731

Ships of the East India Company were called [East
Indiamen](/wiki/East_Indiaman "East Indiaman") or simply "Indiamen".[61]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/Indiaman_Royal_George.jpg/220px-
Indiaman_Royal_George.jpg)](/wiki/File:Indiaman_Royal_George.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Indiaman_Royal_George.jpg "Enlarge")

The East Indiaman _[Royal George](/wiki/Royal_George_\(East_Indiaman\) "Royal
George \(East Indiaman\)")_ , 1779. _Royal George_ was one of the five East
Indiamen the Spanish fleet captured in 1780.

During the period of the [Napoleonic Wars](/wiki/Napoleonic_Wars "Napoleonic
Wars"), the East India Company arranged for [letters of
marque](/wiki/Letter_of_marque "Letter of marque") for its vessels such as the
_Lord Nelson_. This was not so that they could carry cannon to fend off
warships, privateers and pirates on their voyages to India and China (that
they could do without permission) but so that, should they have the
opportunity to take a prize, they could do so without being guilty of piracy.
Similarly, the _Earl of Mornington_ , an East India Company [packet
ship](/wiki/Packet_ship "Packet ship") of only six guns, also sailed under a
letter of marque.

In addition, the company had its own navy, the [Bombay
Marine](/wiki/History_of_the_Indian_Navy "History of the Indian Navy"),
equipped with warships such as _[Grappler](/wiki/HCS_Grappler_\(1804\) "HCS
Grappler \(1804\)")_. These vessels often accompanied vessels of the Royal
Navy on expeditions, such as the [Invasion of
Java](/wiki/Invasion_of_Java_\(1811\) "Invasion of Java \(1811\)").

At the [Battle of Pulo Aura](/wiki/Battle_of_Pulo_Aura "Battle of Pulo Aura"),
which was probably the company's most notable naval victory, [Nathaniel
Dance](/wiki/Nathaniel_Dance "Nathaniel Dance"), Commodore of a convoy of
Indiamen and sailing aboard the _[Warley](/wiki/Warley_\(1796_ship\) "Warley
\(1796 ship\)")_ , led several Indiamen in a skirmish with a French squadron,
driving them off. Some six years earlier, on 28 January 1797, five Indiamen,
the _Woodford_ , under Captain Charles Lennox, the _Taunton-Castle_ , Captain
Edward Studd, _Canton_ , Captain Abel Vyvyan, _Boddam_ , Captain George
Palmer, and ((ship|Ocean|1788 EIC ship|2}}, Captain John Christian Lochner,
had encountered Admiral [de Sercey](/wiki/Pierre_C%C3%A9sar_Charles_de_Sercey
"Pierre César Charles de Sercey") and his squadron of frigates. On this
occasion the Indiamen also succeeded in bluffing their way to safety, and
without any shots even being fired. Lastly, on 15 June 1795, the _General
Goddard_ played a large role in the capture of seven Dutch East Indiamen off
[St Helena](/wiki/Saint_Helena "Saint Helena").

East India Company (EIC)'s ships were well built, with the result that the
[Royal Navy](/wiki/Royal_Navy "Royal Navy") bought several Company ships to
convert to warships and transports. The _Earl of Mornington_ became HMS
_Drake_. Other examples include:

  * [HMS  _Calcutta_ (1795)](/wiki/HMS_Calcutta_\(1795\) "HMS Calcutta \(1795\)")
  * [HMS  _Glatton_ (1795)](/wiki/HMS_Glatton_\(1795\) "HMS Glatton \(1795\)")
  * [HMS  _Hindostan_ (1795)](/wiki/HMS_Hindostan_\(1795\) "HMS Hindostan \(1795\)")
  * [HMS  _Hindostan_ (1804)](/wiki/HMS_Hindostan_\(1804\) "HMS Hindostan \(1804\)")
  * [HMS  _Malabar_ (1804)](/wiki/HMS_Malabar_\(1804\) "HMS Malabar \(1804\)")
  * [HMS  _Buffalo_ (1813)](/wiki/HMS_Buffalo_\(1813\) "HMS Buffalo \(1813\)")

## Records[[edit](/w/index.php?title=East_India_Company&action=edit&section=35
"Edit section: Records")]

Main article: [India Office Records](/wiki/India_Office_Records "India Office
Records")

Unlike all other British Government records, the records from the East India
Company (and its successor the [India Office](/wiki/India_Office "India
Office")) are not in [The National
Archives](/wiki/The_National_Archives_\(United_Kingdom\) "The National
Archives \(United Kingdom\)") at Kew, London, but are held by the [British
Library](/wiki/British_Library "British Library") in London as part of the
[Asia, Pacific and Africa
Collections](/wiki/Asia,_Pacific_and_Africa_Collections,_British_Library
"Asia, Pacific and Africa Collections, British Library"). The catalogue is
searchable online in the _[Access to Archives](/wiki/Access_to_Archives
"Access to Archives")_ catalogues.[62] Many of the East India Company records
are freely available online under an agreement that the [Families in British
India Society](/wiki/Families_in_British_India_Society "Families in British
India Society") has with the British Library. Published catalogues exist of
East India Company ships' journals and logs, 1600–1834;[63] and of some of the
company's daughter institutions, including the East India Company College,
Haileybury, and Addiscombe Military Seminary.[64]
